title: How to Stain Concrete

steps.headline: Inspect the concrete for signs of damage.
steps.description: Look closely for large cracks, chips, crumbling sections, and other signs of damage. Repair moderate damage by filling cracks with a self-sealing concrete crack sealant or putting down a new, thin layer of concrete over heavily worn areas. Stains have a way of accentuating flaws in the surfaces they’re applied to. This means that any imperfections in the concrete may become more visible by the end of your project. If the surface you plan on staining is severely deteriorated, you may want to consider laying new concrete.

steps.headline: Measure your work surface to determine how much stain to buy.
steps.description: One gallon of concrete stain should be enough to cover 200–400 square feet (19–37 m), depending on how heavily it’s applied. For best results, pick up enough stain and sealer to apply 2 coats of each, which will offer more even coverage and superior protection. You’ll find concrete stain and sealer in the paint aisle of any hardware store or home improvement center. Concrete stain is formulated from a semi-transparent base with pigment mixed in, similar to traditional house paint. If you like, you can pick up stains in 2 different colors to give your work surface a marbled effect. Simply use a lighter color as your base coat, then layer a darker shade on top to create depth.Tip: Bring home samples of any stain colors you think you might want to try out. It’s always a good idea to test a stain before covering your entire work surface.

steps.headline: Put down tarps or plastic sheeting to prepare the area for staining.
steps.description: Drape your protective coverings over any nearby items you don’t want the stain to get on, such as grass, shrubs, flower beds, or the stairs of your deck. Once they’re in place, secure the edges using painter’s tape. You might also want to cover things like stepping stones, lawn and garden decorations, and sidewalks and other paved walkways in the immediate vicinity of your work surface.

steps.headline: Clean the concrete surface with a pressure washer or a mild solvent.
steps.description: Use a pressure washer on a moderate pressure setting to blast away dirt and light stains. You can scrub more persistent stains using a stiff-bristled brush and a bucket of distilled white vinegar, hydrogen peroxide, or ammonia. If you opt to use a specialty concrete cleaner instead, be sure to choose a product that’s suitable for the type of concrete you’re staining. pH-neutral cleaners, for instance, are recommended for removing dirt and light stains from sealed concrete surfaces. For especially troublesome stains, like those left by grease and oil, choose an alkaline-based product specifically formulated to be effective on the type of stain you’re dealing with. Otherwise, they may show through the finished stain.

steps.headline: Rinse the concrete thoroughly before you begin staining.
steps.description: Spray down the entire area with a garden hose or pressure washer on a low pressure setting. Continue rinsing until there are no traces of dirt, debris, or cleaning products remaining on your work surface. It’s a good idea to change into a different pair of shoes after cleaning the concrete—you’ll need to be careful not to track dirt or other substances onto the fresh stain.

steps.headline: Add your stain to a paint sprayer.
steps.description: Be sure to dilute the stain according to the directions on the label, if necessary. A sprayer will greatly simplify the application process and provide optimal coverage over broad areas. You can also apply the stain manually using a ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) nap roller if you don’t have access to a sprayer. You may need more than one sprayer if you intend to give your concrete work surface a marbled finish.

steps.headline: Wet the concrete lightly with a garden hose.
steps.description: Most concrete stains are designed to be applied to a damp surface. Hold your thumb over the nozzle of the hose and guide the pressurized stream over your entire work surface. Use just enough water to dampen the concrete—oversaturating it could result in splotchy, uneven coloration. If your hose has an adjustable mist or spray setting, it will work well for this task. Not all concrete stains call for a damp surface. Check the label of the product you’re using to find out whether it will be necessary to wet your concrete.

steps.headline: Spray your first coat of stain onto the concrete in 4 ft (1.2 m) sections.
steps.description: Hold the sprayer wand 20–24 inches (51–61 cm) away from your work surface and sweep it over the concrete using tight circular motions. Aim for full, even coverage. Once you’re done with one section, move onto the next until you’ve completed the entire surface. Start each application with the tip of the wand inside an old bucket or similar container to build up a steady spray before moving it over to your work surface. This container will also be useful for catching runoff from the nozzle afterwards. If you are using 2 different colors to create a marble effect, do not wait to apply the second coat. You can apply it immediately after the first coat.

steps.headline: Backroll the fresh stain with a ⁄8 in (0.95 cm) nap roller.
steps.description: Move the roller back and forth in all different directions to avoid leaving behind roller marks. The textured nap will work the stain deeper into the pores of the concrete, eliminating inconsistencies and giving it a more uniform appearance. You can also use a stiff-bristled brush, paint brush, or sponge to get into tight corners, edges, and other spaces that may be hard to hit directly with larger applicators. A push broom can come in handy for spreading stain over large areas if you don’t have a roller.Tip: Another option is to place a small amount of diluted stain in a spray bottle and use it to touch up areas that look lighter than the surrounding concrete.

steps.headline: Allow the stain to dry overnight.
steps.description: Drying times vary by product, so be sure to consult the manufacturer's directions. In most cases, the stain will dry to the touch within 15-20 minutes and cure fully within 12-24 hours. Avoid walking on or allowing any other objects to come into contact with the concrete as it’s drying.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat after 2-3 hours if you want a deeper color.
steps.description: Spray on the follow-up coat the same way you did the first, moving the wand in tight circles and working in 4 ft (1.2 m) sections. Afterwards, go back over the stain with a roller, brush, or sponge. It shouldn’t be necessary to apply more than 2 coats of stain in total. Only apply a second coat of stain if your concrete is porous enough to hold it. Otherwise, it may be prone to pooling and have difficulty setting. Let your second coat dry for at least 24 hours before sealing or resuming foot traffic on the stained concrete.

steps.headline: Brush the sealer around the edges of the concrete by hand.
steps.description: Dip a 3 in (7.6 cm) paintbrush into the sealer and glide it across the outer 2–3 inches (5.1–7.6 cm) of your work surface in one smooth, thin coat. This will make it easier to apply to the sections of the perimeter that your roller won’t quite reach. Most outdoor concrete sealers are made epoxy or acrylic, which are durable, waterproof, and resistant to slips, scuffs, and UV rays. Indoor sealers tend to be water-based, as these products don’t emit harmful fumes. Sealing your newly-stained concrete is optional, but many home improvement specialists encourage it as it protects the stain from general wear and tear, prevents the initial color from fading, and lends a polished, glossy finish.

steps.headline: Roll a full coat of sealer onto the remaining surface in one direction.
steps.description: Start at one edge of your work surface and push the roller across to the opposite edge, then turn, reposition the roller and work your way back. Repeat this pattern until you’ve covered your entire work surface. As you did with the stain itself, focus on achieving even, consistent, total coverage. Don’t be concerned if the sealer looks white immediately after you apply it—it will dry clear.

steps.headline: Let your first coat of sealer dry for 1-2 hours.
steps.description: Concrete sealers dry to the touch fairly quickly, so you won’t have to wait long before you’re able to apply your second coat. In the meantime, keep clear of your work surface. Any contact with the wet sealer could rub it off, leaving patches of the concrete exposed and unprotected. Check the label of the sealer you’re using for more detailed drying guidelines.

steps.headline: Apply a second coat of sealer perpendicularly to the first.
steps.description: For this coat, roll on each section at a 90-degree angle to the direction you went with your first coat. If you applied your first coat vertically, for example, you’ll apply the second coat horizontally. Layering your coats in this way will ensure that every last crack, crevice, and depression gets filled with the sealer. Be careful not to slather on either coat too thick. Doing so could cause bubbles or large larger blisters to form in the cured finish.Tip: It may help to walk backwards with the roller to avoid stepping on the section of concrete you just rolled.

steps.headline: Allow the sealer to cure for 24 hours.
steps.description: Curing is different from drying, as this is when the sealer will harden to its true finish. After a full day, your concrete surface will be ready to use! If you choose to seal your work surface, it will be important to apply a fresh coat of sealer every 3-4 years to keep it looking its best.
